title: Part of the reason why tank supports are dominating
body:
I've seen this on the comments of another thread and I was thinking.

Nobody wants to be the tank and to protect the carry. Everyone wants to be the carry themselves, especially at lower elos where you can't rely on your team at all to win games. That's why people tend to pick full AD top laners ({{champion:41}} {{champion:92}} {{champion:23}} {{champion:157}} {{champion:114}}), mid lane assassins ({{champion:238}} {{champion:91}} {{champion:7}} {{champion:157}} {{champion:55}}) and damage-oriented junglers ({{champion:64}} {{champion:254}} {{champion:76}} {{champion:11}} {{champion:107}})

Even when people pick champions that are tanky, those champions tend to be bruisers who are still damage oriented and are lacking in utility, peeling potential, and/or teamfighting presence. Also, many of those champions have balancing issues, and people tend to be attracted by "broken" champions. Examples: top ({{champion:86}} {{champion:58}} {{champion:122}} {{champion:2}}) and jungle ({{champion:106}} {{champion:19}} {{champion:59}} {{champion:60}})

Generally people only pick champions who are true tanks when those champions are broken, examples including {{champion:223}}, and {{champion:113}} at the time that she wasn't nerfed. I am not saying that people don't use tanks, it is just that most of time they want to carry and thus they pick champions who have the most potential to carry by themselves. The problem is that by doing that, they are left with a team that has lots of assassins and damage oriented bruisers. But they are lacking on utility and teamfighting potential, can't initiate teamfights, and are very squishy.

And due to that, people who go support are forced to pick tanks to compensate. People generally don't care about what the support want to do and thus they leave the "dirty work" of tanking and initiating for the supports.

This may partially explain why tank supports are so popular. If people were less selfish and thougth more on their team and less about just themselves, and picked top/mid/junglers with more utility and/or tanking potential, I am very sure that this would allow the supports to pick squishier options.

I am not saying that this is the entire reason why tank supports are dominating. Of course there are other problems; for example, AP supports are lacking on good itemization, and tank supports can usually survive for more time to use their utility. Also, I am not saying that a support can't carry on low elo; but lets be honest, it is a lot harder to carry when you are on a position where you are forced not to farm and you are forced to focus on utility/tankyness instead of damage.

The reason people pick tank supports is that they are efficient.

Think about it this way.

Supports are generally champions who have lots of utility in each of their spells, so it stands to reason that you want to use those spells as many times as possible in a teamfight.

There are two ways of doing this, CDR to increase the frequency, and tank stats to increase how long you can fight.

So it stands to reason that supports who benefit from a tanky build with CDR would be more effective.

This is one reason {{champion:16}} , who deals % HP true damage to herself, and {{champion:37}} who needs an AP build to be useful, are seen much less often than {{champion:111}} {{champion:412}} {{champion:201}}, whose spells are all packed with utility, allowing them to build full tank.

Soraka doesn't deal true damage to herself. Her heal costs her own health, if that was true damage to herself then it could be countered by shields.

That said, Soraka generally builds tanky for two reasons. Because she can heal her entire team and win teamfights by herself due to her ult, she is going to be focused. So with a tanky build she can at least survive to heal more despite healing for less. The second reason is that with a Warmog's Armor she can heal pretty much all of her health costs, so it is a good item for her despite having pure health, and is good when coupled with other tanky items.

Getting enough health on soraka to get the warmogs passive requires a lot of time and gold. Plus she's weaker until she gets there since her heals will cost more health, and she'll also get healed less when she lands q (since the health items she typically builds to get the warmogs build doesn't supply a lot of AP).
Spirit Visage is much better than Warmogs for {{champion:16}} - it has increased healing for when she hits enemies with a Starcall, and it has better stats for a caster Support - health, MR, CDR.

She deals a specific type of True Damage (unmitigated by stats) once called 'HP Removal' in DotA. It's true damage so that it can't be mitigated, but coded differently as direct HP Removal so that shields can't mitigate the cost. All health costs have this mechanic. 

She does deal true damage to herself, but a specific kind of true damage.

The REAL problem with squishy supports is that squishy supports can't itemize into mid-lane mage items, but tank supports get to itemize into top-lane tank items. Squishy supports have to settle for 40-60 ap items and shit ap scaling, while tank supports just stack stats as usual. Squishy supports need better ap per item or have stronger ap ratios in their attack moves. That's the only way to fix it.

Dominance of tank supports actually goes back to Preseason 4, when the Utility scaling happened. With more gold to invest in items, yet support options rarely being offensive (I think it was Morello who once said that support items should have crap stats, but godly actives), and reduction on base utility and damage product of the new scaling, the more squishy supports are now unable to poke down their tankier counterparts, all wile granting in general less CC. The tanky supports were mostly unscratched by the scaling utility, and current designs either grant them power for free, or from purchasing defenses.

Janna is the exception since her kit is more defense oriented and, more importantly, is a counter initiator, which prevents the tanky supports from engaging.

Well your team needs at least a tank and a bruiser to have strong team fighting and a real front line.

The goal of mid is to snowball and roam. Mid is a slot for a high damage source. You won't get tanks there.
The goal of the ADC is to snowball, push towers, and provide high damage late game. You won't get tanks there.

That leaves Jungle, Top, and Support. Between those you ideally want to get two tanks.

Top currently favors high damage snowball champions. With GP, Fiora, Darius, and Garen being powerful, you can get a mix of tankiness and damage-- but it is a potential damage slot for your team. So people tend to focus on damage. GP/Fiora/Darius/Garen all also lack great initiation.

So that means you need to get tankiness and initiation from jungle/support.

Jungle roams a lot and more damage helps secure kills from ganks and push towers. However, it's also a good potential source for tanks. But you can't be sure you'll get one, since damage is so valuable there.

Meanwhile you have the support role. It's not really expected to produce damage, so instead you want to focus on the other things that help. Making up for the lack of initiation that may be in top or jg is one of those goals. You also can't count on having two tanks-- so the squishier supports are less valuable.

This puts Leona, Braum, Blitz, Thresh as great picks-- they have initiation (hook displacements and/or CC ults). This makes Tahm good if you have initiate elsewhere because he is tanky.

Basically, since you aren't getting big tanks top or jungle as often, it's more valuable in the support role. 

If we were lacking damage, then Zyra and supports like her would become more valuable. But we aren't. What most teams lack is clear initiation and tankiness. And there are great support options for it.

This is a case where the highest value use of a support at present is tank/initiate. Because the other roles have so many high value damage options which are needed.

For Solo Q it makes sense.
